RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis  

2. 
Rajasthan  is  India’s  largest  state,  with  an  area  of  350,000  square  kilometers  and  a 
population  of  56.5  million  (2001  census).  The  Aravalli  mountain  range  runs  southwest  to 
northeast  across  the  state,  dividing  it  into  two  distinct  geographical  regions—the  Thar  Desert 
covering more than 60% of the state, leaving Rajasthan acutely deficient in water supply, and 
the fertile eastern region. The distribution of the state’s urban centers is related to climate, water 
resources, and soil fertility, with the northeast region more sparsely populated than the eastern 
region.  Rajasthan’s  towns  and  cities  have  always  been  among  the  best  planned  in  India,  but 
rapid population growth over the last four decades has brought urban decline.  
 
3. 
The  state  has  an  urban  population of  around  13.2  million, 23.4%  of its  total  population 
(2001 census). Though lower than the national average of 27.8%, this proportion is expected to 
reach  26.1%  (22.8  million)  by  2021.  The  urban  population  grew  rapidly  in  the  1990s,  by  2.7% 
per  year,  because  of  high  natural  growth  rates  and  rural  migration.  Population  growth  is 
projected  to  slow  down  but  to  remain  high.  In  the  15  initially  identified  Investment  Program 
towns,2 or  urban  local  bodies  (the  Investment  Program  ULBs),  the  population  is  expected  to 
grow by 2–7% per year over the next 10 years.  
 
4. 
Rajasthan’s natural beauty and rich history—about 80% of Indian heritage properties are 
in the state—make it a favorite tourist destination and one of India’s fastest growing. It received 
about 17 million tourists in 2004, and this number is expected to grow to almost 20 million by 
2010.  The  tourism  sector,  directly  or  indirectly,  employs  15  million,  or  24%  of  the  state’s  total 
population.  But  the  sector  accounted  for  just  14%  of  gross  state  domestic  product  (GSDP)  in 
2003–2004,  compared  with  21%  in  Kerala,  the  second-biggest  tourism  state.  To  increase 
economic  growth  and  employment  opportunities,  Rajasthan  needs  to  establish  comparative 
advantage  in  the  tourism  sector  not  only  through  proper  planning  and  developmental  controls 
but also through better public infrastructure and an enabling environment for private investment 
in the sector.  
 
5. 
The  state’s  economy  grew  by  an  average  of  6.2%  per  year  in  1980–2000,  one  of  the 
fastest  among  the  Indian  states.  Since  2000,  however,  annual  growth  rates  have  fluctuated 
significantly.  The  growth  rates  of  9.4%  in  2003,  -6.5%  in  2004,  and  1.5%3 in  2005  indicate 
increasing economic volatility. In addition, severe droughts diminished the agriculture and allied 
sectors, and the investment rate averaged less than 16% of GSDP, well below India’s average 
rate of 23%. While growth has picked up more recently, to 5% in 2005–2006 and 8.5% in 2006–
2007,  and  it  is  the  state’s  utmost  agenda  to  restore  economic  growth  and  closing  the 
development gap.

Rajasthan,  15%  of  the  population  is  living  below  the  poverty  line  (2001  census).  Unlike  other

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  

7. 
The  ADB  supported  project  Rajasthan  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Project 
(RUIDP) 5  has  provided  significant  improvements  in  provision  of  basic  urban  services,  and 
provided capacity development to ULBs to manage urban services in six ULBs. The availability 
of  adequate  urban  services  in  other  urban  centers  however,  are  still  inadequate  because  of 
population pressures, the influx of tourists, and the generally poor management and operation 
of public services common to many cities in India—plus lack of funds. The Investment Program

Investment  Program  Rationale.  The rationale for the Investment Program, apart from 
the national priority of planned development of major urban centers in the country, is economic 
growth and poverty reduction in Rajasthan. The fastest-growing sectors in the state are mostly 
in  the  urban  areas,  where  productivity  is  3.5  times  higher  than  in  the  countryside.  Hence,  the 
Investment  Program  is  designed  to  assist  the  state  in  improving  urban  infrastructure  in  15 
medium-sized  ULBs,  which  were  strategically  selected  to  maximize  the  Investment  Program’s 
contribution to the state’s overall economic growth, while maintaining regional balance. 
 
17. 
A  road  map  for  the  Investment  Program  including  the  investment  needs  of  the  urban 
sector has been prepared (see the Framework  Financing Agreement [FFA] for the Investment 
Program, Schedule 1). In line with the policies of the Government of India and the government 
of  Rajasthan,  it  envisages  a  gradual  transition  to  a  more  efficient  and  accountable  system  of 
urban infrastructure provision and service delivery. Fifteen ULBs in Rajasthan have initially been 
identified  for  assistance  with  their  municipal  functions  (delivery  of  basic  urban  services)  in  the 
Investment  Program,  as  mandated  by  the  74th  Constitution  Amendment  Act  of  India.11 The 
Investment  Program  will  initially  focus  on  investments  in  priority  subsectors,  namely,  urban 
water  supply,  sewerage  and  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  drainage,  transport  and 
roads,  slum  improvement,  and  supporting  infrastructure  for  cultural  heritage.  The  capacity 
development  subcomponent  will  comprise  institutional  strengthening  (computerization  and 
support  for  accounting  reforms),  training,  and  capacity  development,  directly  and  through  the 
City Managers’ Association and the Rajasthan Institute of Local Self Governance, as well as a 
community  action  participation  program.  The  state  government  and  the  ULBs  will  also  be 
assisted in strengthening the reforms already initiated by the government of Rajasthan and the 
Government  of  India,  such  as  those  in  (i)  urban  finance  and  governance  reforms,  for  more 
sustainable  service  delivery;  and  (ii)  sustainable  revenue  generation  through  rationalized  user 
charges and urban-based taxes.  
 
18. 
The  Investment  Program  is  applying  a  sector  loan  approach  to  allow  more  flexible 
investment decisions based on priorities (and constraints) within a sector policy and master plan 
framework, and ensure investments that are linked to reforms through subproject criteria.12 The 
sector loan approach is based on the following: (i) systematic analysis by the state government 
of the main problems in its urban areas, and the recommendations outlined in its 11th Five-Year 
Plan  (FYP),  master  plans,  and  city  development  plans;  (ii)  the  fact  that  the  Executing  Agency 
(EA), the Local Self Government Department (LSGD), is also now implementing the state’s solid 
waste  management  action  plan  and  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Scheme  for  Small  and 
Medium  Towns,  and  that  the  investment  program  will  be  implemented  by  an  investment 
program implementation unit (IPMU), which is an expansion of the existing project management 
unit for RUIDP; and (iii) policies like the draft Water Policy (2006), the Municipal Bill (2006), and 
the draft Urban Housing and Habitat Policy (2007), are currently under finalization.

50. 
All  goods  and  services  to  be  financed  by  the  loans  under  the  Facility  will  be  procured 
according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Civil works 
contracts costing at least $10 million will be procured through international competitive bidding; 
all  other  such  contracts  that  cost  less  than  $10  million  will  be  procured  through  national 
competitive  bidding  (NCB).  As  far  as  practicable,  goods  will  be  procured  in  packages  of  more 
than $1 million to be suitable for international competitive bidding. Otherwise, goods costing less 
than $1 million per contract will be procured through NCB or limited international bidding, and 
miscellaneous  minor  goods  costing  less  than  $100,000  through  shopping.  The  feasibility  of 
community contracting will be examined individually for slum upgrading and low-cost sanitation 
and  other  community  works  costing  up  to  $100,000.  All  NCB  procurement  under  the  loans 
should comply with the procurement procedures agreed on for the Facility and use the standard 
bidding documents approved by ADB. The government of Rajasthan has modified the standard 
NCB  bidding  documents  used  under  RUIDP,  which  were  reviewed  and  accepted  by  ADB  in 
2004, to ensure consistency with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to  time)  and  to  incorporate  lessons  learned  from  the  RUIDP  implementation.  These  bidding 
documents  have  been  reviewed  and  modified  as  necessary  by  ADB  for  consistency  with  the 
updated ADB requirements.

62.

involvement  in  the  Investment  Program,  (ii)  the  goals  of  the  Program,  (iii)  sector  development

economic rationale for government involvement is sound, as the Investment Program supports 
only the basic urban services with monopolistic conditions, externality management, and impact 
on  income  distribution.  The  goals  of  the  Investment  Program  are  consistent  with  the 
Government’s goals of enhancing economic growth and reducing poverty, as clearly reflected in 
the  10th  FYP  and  other  policy  documents.  The  strategy  of  the  Investment  Program,  which 
combines  physical  investments  with  support  for  ongoing  urban  institutional  and  financial 
reforms,  conforms  fully  to  the  Government’s  core  objective  of  linking  funding  to  improved 
institutional performance, as clearly stipulated in the 10th FYP and the recent Jawaharlal Nehru 
National  urban  Renewal  Mission  Program.  The  scope  of  investments  under  the  Investment 
Program  is  based  on  growth  strategies,  city  development  plans  prepared  for  some  of  the 
Investment  Program  ULBs,  available  master  plans,  state  plans,  extensive  consultations 
reflecting  the  priorities  of  all  stakeholders,  demand  projections,  and  assessment  of  the 
institutional absorptive capacity to develop and sustain infrastructure assets.

3. 

Poverty Reduction and Social Development 

66. 
The  Investment  Program  will  widen  access  to  better-quality,  sustainable  urban 
infrastructure  and  services  in  the  Investment  Program  ULBs.  Basic  needs  provision,  living 
conditions,  and  public  health  will  all  improve.  There  will  also  be  broader  benefits,  including 
economic  growth  and  employment  generation.  Safe  drinking  water  is  a  basic  need  that  is  not 
easily  accessible  to  a  significant  number  of  poor  people  in  the  ULBs.  According  to  baseline 
surveys,21 piped water is accessible through household connections to 19% of those living in the 
slums  of  Jhalawar,  and  to  39%  of  those  in  slums  in  Alwar.  Better  access  to  water  of  better 
quality will also ease the burden of water collection (1 hour per day) on vulnerable segments of 
the  population,  particularly  for  women.  Low  water  connection  fees  (paid  in  installments)  and 
lifeline tariffs will make drinking water more affordable to the poor. None of the slum areas in the 
three sample ULBs have underground sewerage systems; only 7% of the households in those 
areas  reportedly  have  individual  toilets,  and  more  than  70%  resort  to  open  defecation. 
Sewerage  networks  will  reach  the  boundaries  of  slum  areas  and  give  a  large  number  of 
households access to low-cost toilets. The collection and disposal of waste is highly irregular. In 
the  slum  areas,  more  than  75%  of  the  households  dispose  of  waste  along  nearby  roads. 
Improvements in sewage treatment, sanitation, and solid waste management will improve public 
health and reduce the burden of disease, treatment costs, and productivity losses, particularly 
among the poor. The urban road and cultural heritage components will benefit poor households 
through  employment  generation  and  access.  The  impact  of  improved  urban  services  on  the 
urban  poor  will  be  monitored  closely  during  project  implementation.  The  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 9.

asset sustainability. The government of Rajasthan has prepared a transition plan for transfer of

manage the assets.

1. 
Formed only in 1956, Rajasthan had a late start in development and with relatively slow 
growth  in  the  1960s  and  1970s  lagged  further  behind  the  other  Indian  states.  But  Rajasthan 
started  to  close  the  development  gap  in  the  1980s,  and  growth  rates  accelerated  sharply, 
reaching 6.2% in 1980–2000, one of the highest among Indian states; poverty fell significantly, 
from 27% in 1994 to 15% in 2000, and several human development indicators1 showed notable 
improvements.  The  high  growth  rates  were  driven  by  rapid  growth  in  industry  and  services, 
which  created  a  more  diversified  economy  and  lowered  volatility;  investments  in  irrigation, 
electricity,  and  road  connectivity;  and  an  increase  in  human  capital.  Since  then,  however,  the 
state’s growth performance has faltered, threatening the progress made over the last 7 years. 
Since  2000,  annual  growth  rates  have  fluctuated  significantly,  from  9.4%  in  2003  to  -6.5%  in 
2004 and 1.5% in 2005, indicating increasing economic volatility. Three droughts in the past 5 
years, rapidly depleting groundwater levels, and falling investment rates have all contributed to 
decelerating growth. While the growth rate has picked up in recent years, to 5% in 2006 and 8% 
in 2007, the state is determined to revive growth and close the development gap.  
 
2. 
The level of urbanization (24% in the 2001 census) in the state is less than that of India

urbanization to increase to 26% by  2012, and the 222 urban towns in the state to increase to 
230 by 2012. The majority of the urban population (57%) is concentrated in 20 towns, each with 
a population of more than 100,000. Future population growth rates are projected to decline but 
will  remain  high.  The  population  of  the  15  initially  identified  urban  local  bodies  (ULBs)  to  be

areas  in  pursuit  of  economic  opportunities,  more  and  more  slums  are  emerging  in  the  urban 
areas: more than 20% of the urban population currently lives in slums. A survey conducted in 
three  Investment  Program  ULBs3  showed  that the  percentage  of  slum  population ranged  from 
4% in Jhalawar-Jhalapatan and 7% in Alwar to 27% in Jaisalmer.

LESSONS LEARNED FROM URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS IN INDIA 

 
1. 
Compared with other infrastructure sectors in India, the urban sector provides a unique 
opportunity  for  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  make  a  direct  contribution  to  achieving 
the  Millennium  Development  Goals  through  extensive  improvements  in  basic  urban  social 
services  to  urban  dwellers,  including  the  urban  poor.  Besides  their  most  evident  impact—
improved living conditions and quality of life for urban dwellers—such projects have longer-term 
economic benefits arising from the overall improvement in living conditions.  
 
To  the  state  executing  agencies,  ADB  assistance  is  much  more  than  filling  the  gap  in 
2. 
funding  for  the  construction  or  rehabilitation  of  urban  infrastructure.  The  assistance  gives  the 
state  governments  the  opportunity  to  (i)  get  long-term  capacity  development  support  during 
project  implementation  (5–7  years);  (ii)  apply  more  transparency  and  higher  standards  in 
procurement;  and  (iii)  focus  on  adequate  operation  and  maintenance  of  urban  services, 
ensuring the sustainability of urban projects.  
 
3. 
The  goal  of  improving  basic  urban  services  has  been  translated  into  actions  through 
mostly  integrated  urban  projects  combining  infrastructure  development  and  environmental 
improvements  with  targeted  poverty  reduction,  urban  institutional  reforms,  and  capacity 
development.  Despite  the  noble  goal,  however,  the  implementation  of  urban  projects  has  not 
been without problems. In fact, significant delays have been common because integrated urban 
development  projects  are  inherently  complex  and  their  implementation  requires  close 
coordination between several agencies, enhanced institutional capacity, and public support. The 
resulting  time  and  cost  overruns  have  been  found  to  be  too  costly,  despite  the  proven 
advantage  of  the  integrated  design  of  urban  projects.  As  a  result,  a  new  framework  was 
developed  and  agreed  for  stronger  ownership  of  the  projects  by  the  state  and  municipal 
governments  at  an  early  stage  of  project  design  and  implementation.  The  new  framework 
includes up-front capacity development of implementing agencies and institutional strengthening 
of  state  line  departments  to  reduce  start-up  delays  and  strengthen  the  focus  on  integrating 
lessons  learned  from  earlier  urban  development  projects.  The  key  lessons  learned  and 
measures included in the Investment Program design are summarized below.  
 
4. 
Longer-Term  Assistance.  It  is  difficult  to  achieve  the  intended  impact,  especially  in 
urban governance and management improvement, through a single intervention. ADB projects 
have  been  instrumental  in  building  stronger  state  nodal  agencies  in  the  urban  sector.  For 
example,  the  Karnataka  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Finance  Corporation,  an  executing 
agency  for  two  ADB-financed  projects,  emerged  as  a  nodal  agency  for  the  development, 
financing,  and  implementation  of  urban  projects.  It  prepared  the  third  loan  from  ADB  without 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance.  Similarly,  the  project  management  unit  of  Rajasthan 
Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Project  (RUIDP)  I  can  now  carry  out  most  of  the  advance 
actions for the Investment Program without detailed supervision from ADB. To be effective, ADB 
assistance  should  be  made  over  a  longer  term,  through  successive  loans  to  the  beneficiary 
state.  
  
5. 
Start-Up Delays. As indicated earlier, there were abnormal delays in initial activities by 
the executing agencies (EAs) during the project start-up period. It was apparent that the support 
of consultants would be required not just during detailed engineering design and supervision but 
also  during  project  preparation.  Earlier,  in  the  absence  of  retroactive  financing,  state 
governments  had  to  wait  for  the  loans  to  be  signed  and  take  effect  before  mobilizing 
consultants. For this very reason, under RUIDP, it took 18 months to appoint loan consultants 
after  loan  signing.  Such  initial  delays  in  the  appointment  of  consultants  considerably  affects 
subsequent  project  implementation  since  the  preparation  of  generic  prequalification  and 
standard  bidding  documents,  detailed  engineering  surveys,  and  preparation  of  specific  tender 
documents  take  place  only  after  the  loan  consultants  are  in  place.  As  a  result,  in  the  case  of

RUIDP,  it  took  another  year  after  the  appointment  of  the  consultants,  or  more  than  2.5  years 
after the loan was signed, to award the first major civil works contract.  
 
6. 
To overcome these start-up delays, extensive discussions and reviews were carried out 
in  2003–2004  for  urban  sector  projects  in  India.  On  the  borrower’s  side,  it  was  agreed  that  a 
dedicated  project  management  unit  would  be  set  up  during  project  appraisal.  Unlike 
experienced national agencies such as the National Highway Authority of India or other central 
public  sector  undertakings,  state  governments  and  local  urban  bodies  do  not  have  dedicated 
project  management  units  at  the  time  of  project  appraisal.  ADB  for  its  part  agreed  to  provide 
support to the EAs in: (i) establishing project management and implementation units far ahead 
of  loan  effectiveness;  (ii) strengthening  the  managerial  and  institutional  capabilities  of  such 
units; (iii) assisting in the preparation of tender documents, the selection of consultants, and the 
prequalification  of  contractors;  (iv) familiarizing project  staff  with  ADB  policies  and procedures; 
and  (v) ensuring  a  strong  sense  of  ownership  by  the  state  and  municipal  governments,  and 
promoting public participation. Therefore, a bridging technical assistance (TA), advance actions, 
and  the  strengthening  of  institutions  responsible  for  project  implementation  have  been 
incorporated in the Investment Program to avoid start-up delays.  
 
7. 
Project Readiness. Project readiness, in terms of not only the advance setting up and 
staffing of the project management unit and project implementation units but also actions toward 
the attainment of land and regulatory clearances for the sites, is very important for the speedy 
implementation  of  projects.  Of  particular  concern  is  land  acquisition,  which  is  normally  the 
primary  cause  of  delay  in  implementing  urban  infrastructure  projects.  Under  RUIDP,  great 
difficulties  in  land  acquisition  were  experienced  during  implementation,  particularly  for  the 
sewage  treatment  plants  (STPs).  For  instance,  due  to  legal  issues  related  to  land  acquisition, 
the  STP  in  Udaipur  had  to  be  dropped  from  the  project.  Similarly,  the  implementation  of 
activities  in  Ajmer  was  substantially  delayed  by  land  acquisition  for  the  STP.  Similarly,  the 
process  of  obtaining  statutory  and  other  approvals  from  concerned  authorities,  such  as  the 
pollution control  boards  and  national  highway  or  railway  authorities, causes  delays  and  hence 
needs to begin before loan approval. Such actions have already started for the subprojects and 
sites  under  the  first  tranche  of  the  Investment  Program,  and  the  investment  program 
management unit (IPMU) has been established as well. During preparation of the RUSDIP, the 
authorities have displayed a considerable sense of ownership and reform momentum.  
 
Change  in  Scope.  Urban  development  projects  often  undergo  changes  in  scope  to 
8. 
respond  to  the  evolving  needs  of  the  urban  communities.  Changes  in  scope,  processing,  and 
preparation  in  earlier  projects  in  Rajasthan  and  Karnataka,  particularly  in  the  assessment  of 
compliance  with  safeguards,  further  delayed  project  implementation.  Therefore,  the  scope  of 
each  loan  under  the  Investment  Program  will  be  well  defined  in  close  consultation  with 
stakeholders.  
 
9. 
Tariff  Reforms.  Even  small  changes  generally  take  years  to  incorporate  in  tariff 
structures  and  reforms,  and  there  is  a  need  for  modest  but  focused  incremental  reforms.  In 
particular, policy changes such as increases in water supply and sewerage tariffs are likely to be 
more acceptable if these are preceded by infrastructure development, improvement of services, 
and  extensive  stakeholder  consultations.  Under  the  Investment  Program,  the  rationalization  of 
tariffs  is  proposed  to  be  introduced  in  accordance  with  JNNURM  principles.  Additional 
awareness-raising  campaigns  will  be  undertaken  and  extensive  stakeholder  consultations  will 
continue during the implementation of the Program.  
 
10.  Market-Based  Cost  Estimates  and  Minimization  of  Contract  Packages.  Cost 
estimates in urban projects are generally based on the standard schedule of rates (SOR). The 
SOR,  normally  developed  for  much  smaller  works  and  not  updated  regularly,  is  therefore  an 
inadequate foundation for estimating costs for large-scale urban infrastructure projects. As was

found  in  RUIDP  as  well  as  other  urban  development  projects,  the  prices  obtained  through 
competitive  bidding  can  be  significantly  different  from  the  cost  estimates  (by  35–75%  in  many 
cases), necessitating negotiation, cancellation and re-bidding, and repackaging. Therefore, it is 
proposed  that  a  basic  schedule  of  rates  (BSR)  based  on  the  index  of  basic  materials  like 
cement,  steel,  and  pipes,  be  prepared  for  the  Investment  Program.  The  BSR,  to  be  updated 
every  6  months  to  reflect  market  fluctuations  and  inflation,  will  be  used  in  preparing  cost 
estimates  for  the  subprojects  under  the  Program.  This  mechanism  of  reflecting  the  cost 
estimates on updated market based rates will facilitate implementation and the management of 
contracts  by  reducing  bid  processing  delays  and  the  variations  that  are  often  observed  in  the 
implementation of urban projects. Similarly, to minimize the number of contracts and maximize 
contractor  and  market  participation,  measures  such  as  combining  the  procurement  of  similar 
equipment (for example, bulk water meters, pump machineries, solid waste equipment) will be 
centralized, and  contract  packages,  such  as  the  design  and  construction  of  sewage  treatment 
plants, will be combined for neighboring urban local bodies (ULBs) eligible for funding under the 
Investment Program. 
 
11. 
Capacity  Building  of  ULBs  to  Manage  the  Assets.  Capacity  building  and  staffing  of 
ULBs  with  enough  resources  to  run  and  maintain  the  completed  project  facilities  generally 
received  limited  attention.  To  address  this  issue  and  maximize  the  sustainability  of  assets 
created  under  the  Investment  Program,  a  draft  institutional  and  capacity  development  plan 
(Supplementary  Appendix  N)  has  been  prepared  by  the  bridging  TA  consultants,  and  will  be 
further developed by the IPMU with the support of loan consultants. Furthermore, the design of 
the  implementation  structure  of  the  Investment  Program  took  into  careful  consideration  the 
number of subsectors and subprojects, and the absorptive as well as implementation capacity of 
the EA and the ULBs. 
 
12. 
Focus on Stakeholder Involvement. Under RUIDP, the community action participation 
program  (CAPP),  which  was  to  promote  community  awareness  and  the  involvement  of  local 
communities in the project, did not start when the project was first implemented. Therefore, the 
communities  did  not  participate  in  the  planning,  and  felt  excluded  from  the  project  benefits. 
Furthermore, community awareness activities should have focused more on advocacy, i.e., on 
payment  for  improved  service  facilities,  to  ensure  that  urban  dwellers  understood  the 
importance  of  user  charges  for  the  sustainability  of  project  activities.  Finally,  in  RUIDP  the 
community  infrastructure  improvements  proposed  by  local  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs)  took  too  long  to  be  approved,  such  that  most  were  never  approved.  The  Investment 
Program  design  includes  the  implementation  of  CAPP  activities  at  the  start  of  Program 
implementation,  extensive  awareness-raising  activities  and  emphasis  has  been  placed  on 
simplified procedures.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reducing poverty in India/Rajasthan:  
 
With a population of over 56 million (2001 census) Rajasthan is India’s eighth-largest state. The population growth rate 
in  Rajasthan  was  28%  in  1991–2001,  higher  than  the  national  growth  rate  of  21.3%  during  the  same  period.  The 
urbanization level in the state increased from 17.6% in the 1971 census to 23.4% (13.2 million) of the total population in 
the 2001 census, slightly lower than the national average of 27.8%, and it is expected to reach 26.1% (22.8 million) by 
2021. The population living below the poverty line has decreased significantly, from 27.4% in 1994, to 15.2% in 2000. 
According to a recent survey by the government of Rajasthan, the percentage of the population living below the poverty 
line (BPL) increased slightly to 19% in 2004. In contrast to the national trend, Rajasthan’s urban poverty level is higher 
than the rural poverty level. In 1994, the rural poor constituted 26.4% and the urban poor 30.4%, and in 2000 the rural 
poor made up 13.7% and the urban poor 19.8%. Higher urban poverty rates and an expanding urban population may, 
in  the  coming  years,  lead  to  an  urban  crisis  already  compounded  by  lack  of  water  and  a  stagnant  manufacturing 
industry. It is also important to note that a large group of people remain just above the statistical cut-off poverty line. A 
recent report by The World Bank observes that raising the relevant income poverty line by 10% would raise the urban 
poverty level by 34% and rural poverty by 20% at the aggregate national level.  
 
Additionally, income poverty does not accurately reflect all the dimensions of poverty in Rajasthan. The transient nature 
of  poverty  in  Rajasthan,  due  to  natural  disasters,  makes  the  condition  of  the  poor  particularly  precarious.  Frequent 
drought and the resulting large-scale out-migration in search of employment have a severe impact on the poor that is 
not  reflected  in  a  quantitative  assessment.  Furthermore,  income  poverty  hides  many  other  dimensions  of  human 
suffering, which are accentuated by ecological factors and inadequate provisioning of basic amenities.  
 
The slowdown in growth since the end of the 1990s is threatening the state’s prospects for achieving the Millennium 
Development  Goals  (MDGs).  Rajasthan  seems  on  the  way  to  achieving  the  goals  for  primary  education  and 
environmental sustainability, if growth rates and other conditions remain favorable, but the state is unlikely to succeed 
in achieving the goals of reducing infant and child mortality and providing reproductive health services for all. The state 
has made remarkable progress in primary education: the primary gross enrollment ratio increased from 89% in 1993 to 
97%  in  2002  and  to  more  than  100%  in  2004.  On  the  other  hand,  health  indicators  are  behind  those  for  the  rest  of 
India, as highlighted by the fact the underweight children per 1,000 and under-5 mortality per 1,000 actually increased, 
rather  than  decreased,  in  the  1990s.  Since  human  development/social  indicators  are  closely  correlated  with  income, 
economic recovery is highly relevant to the achievement of the MDGs.  
 
The  Rajasthan  Urban  Sector  Development  Investment  Program  is  expected  to  address  basic  needs  deficiencies 
throughout 15 medium-sized cities and boost the regional economy through improved urban services. Direct benefits 
will be sustained improvements in basic services in all Investment Program ULBs. The Investment Program will have a 
positive impact on the poor. Safe drinking water is a basic need that is inaccessible to a significant number of the poor 
in Rajasthan. The Program and the facilities to be built or improved under it will reduce the burden of water collection 
on vulnerable  segments of the population such as  women. Free  water connections and lifeline tariffs  will ensure that 
the poor can afford clean drinking water. Improvements in the quality of water, sewage treatment, sanitation, and solid 
waste  management  will  lead  to  public  health  improvements  and  hence  to  reductions  in  the  burden  of  diseases, 
treatment cost, and productive losses, whose impact is felt by the poor in particular. Women, especially poor women, 
will  benefit  from  the  reduction  in  the  time  and  energy  spent  in  fetching  and  storing  water,  and  in  the  work  burden 
associated  with  cleaning  and  family  health  care.  The  spin-offs  are  expected  to  be  economic  growth  and  direct 
employment in unskilled or construction work under the Investment Program.

A  baseline  socioeconomic  survey  was  conducted  in  three  of  the  Investment  Program  towns  (Alwar,  Jaisalmer  and

Even though progress in access to improved water and sanitation in urban areas is on track in Rajasthan in terms of 
achieving the MDGs, significant urban population growth rates and unequal distribution of basic urban services in urban 
areas  may  cause  a  setback  in  achieving  the  MDGs.  According  to  the  baseline  socioeconomic  survey,  the  population 
living below the poverty line (BPL) was 18% in Alwar, 8% in Jaisalmer, and 25.9% in Jhalawar-Jhalapatan. The slum

the poor quality of urban environmental infrastructure and a gap in basic urban services, particularly for the poor living 
in slum areas.   
 
The  social  and  poverty  analysis  showed  widespread  deficiencies  in  basic  urban  services  in  the  three  cities.  Around 
76% of households in slums in Jaisalmer do not have access to water service connections. Although public stand posts 
exist, issues of water pressure and frequency and duration of supply are major issues for the poor. The survey revealed 
that in Jaisalmer, water is supplied through the stand posts only once or twice a week. In summer, slum dwellers have 
to look for drinking water in other colonies with no certainty of getting it. More than 70% of slum households in the three 
towns  do  not  have  private  toilets  and  60%  practice  open  defecation.  Drainage  systems  do  not  exist  in  Jhalawar  and 
Jhalapatan,  while  in  Alwar  drainage  systems  are  availably  only  in  a  limited  area.  In  Jaisalmer,  only  2%  of  poor 
households  reportedly  have  drainage  connections.  Lack  of  drainage,  resulting  in  regular  waterlogging  and  flooding 
during  rains,  was  reported  by  24%  slum  dwellers  in  Jhalawar,  and  for  62%  of  the  slum  population  in  all  three  towns 
solid  waste  is  not  collected  regularly.  Solid  waste  disposal  is  usually  on  nearby  roads  or  roadside  drains  because  of 
poor  municipal  waste  collection  and  disposal.  With  this  low  access  to  basic  services,  waterborne  diseases  such  as 
diarrhea,  enteric  fever,  and  viral  hepatitis  are  significant  in  the  towns.  The  prevalence  of  diarrhea  among  the  poor  is 
41% in Jaisalmer and 46% in Alwar. Deficiencies in environmental sanitation are the cause of waterborne diseases, a 
major contributor to high levels of morbidity and mortality. Thus, the control of these diseases needs to be addressed 
through improved sanitation and supply of safe drinking water.  
 
The provision of good-quality and sustainable services to promote economic development and reduce poverty will rely 
on support from the Investment Program in building the capacity of the urban local bodies to plan and manage more 
effectively. The Investment Program will improve capacity to plan, develop, and operate pro-poor urban infrastructure 
and  services  on  the  basis  of  an  improved  understanding  of  poverty  and  processes  of  participatory  planning  and 
development.  
 
Poverty and social analysis using a combination of qualitative and quantitative techniques is required to gauge post–
Investment Program benefits in terms of improved access to basic services by the poor. The baseline survey will serve 
as  the  benchmark  against  which  post–Investment  Program  impact  on  the  poor  may  be  measured.  Benefits  to  poor 
households,  benefits  to  women,  and  increased  participation  and  capacity  building  of  the  poor  including  women  are 
some of the issues that must be monitored and measured during and after implementation.

D.  Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize beneficial impacts on women: 
Primary  and  secondary  information  has  been  analyzed  to  assess  the  status  of  women  in  Investment  Program  ULBs. 
While there are significant differences in the status of women in the different Investment Program ULBs, the trends are 
common. In terms of education the female literacy rate is lower the rate for men. Social, economic, and cultural barriers 
prevent poor women from obtaining easy access to health services and care, even when good-quality health services 
are geographically within reach.  
 
The lack of basic urban infrastructure and services affects women more than men. Because of women’s primary role in 
managing the household, the burden of water collection falls on them. During Investment Program preparation it was 
noted  that  water  collection  takes  3–4  hours  per  day  for  women.  This  reduces  the  time  they  have  to  engage  in 
productive activities that would increase household income and improve women’s position within the households. Lack 
of  clean  water  supply  also  burdens  women,  who  handle  water  more  than  men.  Women  have  higher  exposure  to 
diseases  from  contaminated  water  in  the  process  of  collecting  water,  and  using  water  in  cooking  and  washing.  A 
reduction in diseases, aside from reducing the costs of treatment and productivity losses, also reduces the burden of 
caring  for  sick  household  members  which,  is  often  a  role  taken  on  by  women  in  the  household.  The  lack  of  toilet 
facilities also has a large impact on women in terms of privacy. The Investment Program responds to these issues in 
the design of its subprojects.

Introduction and Description of the Investment Program 

A. 
 
1. 
The  Investment  Program  will  optimize  social  and  economic  development  in  15  selected 
towns1  in  Rajasthan  through  investments  in  urban  infrastructure  (water  supply,  wastewater 
management,  solid  waste  management,  urban  drainage,  and  urban  transport  and  roads),  social 
infrastructure,  and  infrastructure  support  for  cultural  heritage.  The  Investment  Program  will  also 
provide  policy  reforms  to  strengthen  urban  governance,  management,  and  support  for  urban 
infrastructure  and  services.2  Initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  for  sample  subprojects3 
(Supplementary Appendix J) and an overall summary IEE were prepared. The IEEs were based on 
field  surveys,  secondary  information,  and  discussions  with  stakeholders.  Salient  points  from  the 
IEEs are summarized below. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The Investment Program is designed to maximize environmental and public health benefits. 
IEEs  conducted  for  the  Investment  Program  show  that  net  subproject  environmental  benefits  are 
positive  and  large  including:  increases  in  quantity  and  improvements  in  quality  of  drinking  water 
from  water  supply  subprojects;  better  public  health,  particularly  reduction  in  waterborne  diseases 
through  water  supply,  sewerage,  drainage,  solid  waste  management  investments;  improved 
aesthetics  from  sewerage,  drainage,  and  solid  waste  management  works;  reduced  flooding 
through drainage improvement; reduced exposure to suspended particulates and to noise pollution 
through  urban  transport  and  road  components;  and  social  benefits  from  slum  improvement  and 
civic  infrastructure  outputs.  The  potential  negative  subproject  impact  during  construction  and 
operation  will  not  be  significant  because  larger  facilities  will  be  located  in  low-density  and 
nonsensitive areas, the works will be small in scale and the construction period short, and simple 
technologies  will  low  maintenance  requirements  will  be  preferred.  The  Investment  Program  does 
not have any cumulative impact but is designed to support the state government in developing the 
covered sectors. In the longer term (beyond the Investment Program period), sector-wide positive 
impact is envisioned.

have  any  significant  negative  environmental  impact  and  no  impact  on  environmentally  sensitive 
areas.  Subprojects  with  potentially  significant  and  permanent  impact  will  not  be  allowed.  The
